text: Draught. Pours a hazy amber-y gold with a medium, foamy off-white head. Aroma is mango, citrus, pine, dough, floral hops, and light soap. Taste is mango, bread, grass, pine, some lemon, and resin. Tiny amount of buried grapefruit. Slightly earthy finish. Moderately bitter, although it grows in bitterness the more you drink. Light-medium body. Moderate carbonation. Creamy-ish mouthfeel. Mouth is lighter than expected - almost a touch watery - and resin is a bit palate fatiguing. Taste is surprisingly soft.

Bottle: Poured a clear yellow color ale with a nice large pure white foamy head with good retention and excellent lacing. Aroma if dominated by strong citrusy undertones with some light grassy and piney notes also noticeable. Taste is a mix of strong citrusy hops notes with some light grassy notes with light pale malt also noticeable. Body is about average with excellent carbonation. Solid IPA with almost no bitterness and lots of delicate flavours.
Fraught at Harrys Hofbrau in San Jose. Slightlyhazy yellow-gold with retained white head that collars. Pine dominates aroma and flavor. Sweet and moderate high bittering.

Draught at Toronado. Slightly hazy yellow color, white head. Bitter taste with grapefruit, hops, mango, a bit of resin, pine and grass. Bitter finis grapefruit, hops, pine, mango and a bit of grass. Excellent IPA.

500ml bottle, slight orange blonde hue, with a thick white head, very nice herbal floral tropical fruit, leafy, soapy, citrusy, grassy hoppy nose, with some yeasty, bready, doughy, faint lemon marmalade, faint panettone cake dough, cedary, faint lemon, orange rind accents, and a subtle piney, lemon tea leaf, lemon pie crust note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate fruity, yeasty, doughy, lemon pie crust, candied zesty grapefruit, lemon peel character, with some flowery citrusy, leafy, grassy, cedary, piney hoppy, fruity yeasty, doughy, toasted, pale, wheat malt flavours, leading towards a bread yeastiness, zesty grapefruit rind, lingering citrusy, piney, leafy, grassy hop bitterness finish.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2017 Draft at Bru Craft. Hazy yellow gold pour with a good show of off-white foam. Lots of lace. Strong hop notes with soft edges. Spruce tips. Lemon zest. Bamboo. Apricot. Varnish. Easy drinking but packs a flavorful hop punch. Dry. Well balanced.

Tap at Cap Tap. Pours translucent gold with a white head. Aroma is mild fruit with a touch of evergreen. Med body. Flavor is citrus/pine and pale fruits with moderate caramel support. Bitter enough, hoppy enough to think dank is near. Really well balanced and very tasty.
On tap. Poured a lemon yellow wheat with a slight haze. Very lacy white head. Palate is dry lemon pine balanced against a saltine crackers grain. Crisp mouth. Clean dry finish. Yum.

Tap. Reservoir, Waterbury, VT. Just about clear, bright gold. Film of lasting, clingy, white head. Nose has squeaky clean pine, and minty, hop. Marmalade on toast backdrop. Notes of pine needle and sappy wood. Taste is sappy sweet, getting resinous and slick bitter. Light to medium body. Well carbonated, cutting through the sappy chew. Long, light, resinous bitter finish. Great stuff.

Funny that the first thing I noticed was how west coast this tasted for an east coast IPA... Draft pour. Slightly hazy yellow orange in color... Aroma is bursting with tropical fruits, mango. Flavor is dry, lots of tropical hops... Delicious

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

strong citrusy aroma of those similar to cascade, centennial, and citra. golden and hazy with nice long lasting head. Taste is hop forward but has malty notes. Not overly bitter and finishes smoothly.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Smileys Discount Beverage. Appearance is lightly hazy, light gold with beautiful sparkle, 2+ finger-width white creamy head with good retention and nice soapy lacing. Aroma is citrus, tropical fruit, mild dank earthy resin, herbs. Taste is tropical fruit with citrus and light resin with second half toasted bready malt. Palate is medium-to-full bodied with thick texture, average carbonation and mix of fruity/bready finish. Overall, a superb beer that tastes and feels more like a DIPA than just an IPA. I usually find their IPAs too bitter but this one is more restrained and focused on flavor. Well done.

Bottle shared by Kyle, thanks! Pours cloudy peachy orange with a white head that dissipates to the edges slowly. Aroma has a lot of citrus with a bit of earthiness and a light grain backbone. Flavor has lots of bitter citrus with a slight earthiness and a bit of sweet grain backing.
Smooth great balance. Liked the tropical notes on this beer. Very drinkable and not overrated. Glad to try this one!
Bottle at tasting. Aroma of hop, citrus, malt and pine. Taste has fresh fruit, citrus, grassy fresh hops and mild pine. Nice stuff, bit overrated though.

Maine Beer Company Lunch. Espetáculo de cerveja. Belíssima IPA, frutado absurdo, final limpo, ZERO harsh. Como toda IPA deve ser. 4.5/5

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a slight hazy golden with a fair white head which lingered......aroma of citrus, nothing but citrus......taste is clean, crisp, sweet bread, sweet malt, pine, clean, wonderful mouthfeel. Well built.

It poured a deep gold color, with finger width head. It smelled like citrus and floral hops. Also smells very "clean" if that makes sense. It is super smooth and has a very nice hop/malt balance. Possibly, a perfect hop/malt balance. The hops linger on the tongue just a little bit in the finish, but not too bitter.

Bottle: &nbsp Thanks to Sloth for this one. &nbsp Cloudy straw, orangish, big fluffy white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Hoppy nose, but not bitter. &nbsp A little sweet and citrusy, slightly candied. &nbsp Similar on the tongue. &nbsp Very smooth. &nbsp Nice hop profile without being overly bitter. &nbsp Citrusy start to finish, but without the bitterness. &nbsp Moderate to full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Clean finish. &nbsp Really easy drinking IPA. &nbsp It could actually stand to have a bit more bitterness, HAHAH.

Une bière ambrée, avec une bonne carbonatation et petite effervescence. Au nez, les odeurs dhoublons sont puissantes - ananas, oranges et pamplemousses, ce qui est tres prometteur pour la suite. En bouche, cest tout autant houblonné, avec un petit côté résineux quon ne trouvait pas au nez. Les saveurs ressenties au nez sont un peu moins présentes en bouche, dû à lamertume assez solide en bouche. En bref, une IPA assez classique de ce quon voit de la west coast - bien faite mais en même temps, pas aussi extraordinaire que sont "hype" le veut.
Love this beer!! The only reason its not my top beer is that I prefer the MO better!

Tap into a snifter showing a finger of clean white foam and lightly filtered dry orange peel. 

The nose shows sharp notes of cannabis and tart kiwi with steel tank notes in between. 

The palate is light bodied and fully carbonated. Flavors of juicy kiwi, pineapple and lighter notes of mango. Moderate hoppy bitterness that balances the fruit flavors and a light zesty spice on the linger. I had this in a bottle before and have to say, having it fresh on tap is completely different.

Maine lunch is a damn good ipa. Crisp a hoppy and citrusy. The aroma was fantastic. Love this beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very smooth hoppy, non malty flavor. Slightly cloudy blond. Good but I dont get all the hype.

Lunch has a golden frothy pour with honey notes In the aroma with a dusky pine forest thing going on too.
Really nice and floral palate. Smooth.

On tap at SLL tasting and 500ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy yellow capped with a thick layer of soapy bubbles. Aroma is fresh, and hoppy. Zesty citrus, floral hops, peach skin, grass, and, pine. Smooth vibrant hop flavors over a bed of fresh grain...zesty lemon and grapefruit, juicy fruit, herbs, and flowers . Soft, dry, crisp feel - drinks lighter than the ABV would suggest.

Sampler (8oz pours?) from Appalachian Vintners. Orange copper pour with an off-white head. Terrific nose. Very hoppy. Clean. Sweet fruit and light sweet malts. Taste is of citrus & pine and light sweet malts. Finishes tangy bittersweet, slightly to the sweet side. The blend is very well done. This is very very tasty. 16.2

Very piney, some citrus but not nearly as much as one would expect from a new england IPA, this is more Pacific northwestern. Smells funky, but not skunky, very smooth, crisp mouthfeel, very crushable.

Orange pour, white head. Nose is grapefruit, hop resin, piney. Taste is grapefruit, other citrus, hop oils. Oily mouthfeel with a bitter finish. My first thought was this is very much like a west coast IPA, so it was no surprise reading the description. Thanks Thim!

Hazy yellow orange pour with a lasting white head. Lacing coats the glass. Strong peach, orange, floral and pine aroma. Taste is peach, citrus zest, floral, pine, and light spicy hop. Lingering orange peel aftertaste. Soft carbonation. Medium body. Really easy drinking. Awesome.

On draft at Caps & Taps. It pours a lightly hazed yellow/orange color with a thick white head. The aroma has soft melon and peach with hints of flowers and dank. Nice. The flavor has some strong hop spice along with the peach, pine and some grapefruit. Definitely more spicy and dank than the fruity aroma. Soft, creamy mouthfeel and well carbonated. It has a light graham cracker malt character in the background supporting a pretty dry beer with strong spicy bitterness. A bit more bitter than I like my IPAs, but this one was very strong in every other category.

28 June 2016, tap. Yellow and a tad hazy/dirty. Nose is sweet, orange, grapefruit, lemon citrus. Med body and mildly fizzy. Dry citrus and mildly malty. I think an east coast IPA should be sweeter and a bit more body. But this is a "blend." Still, very good.
On tap at capitol beer. Pours orange copper with white head. Taste is lots of citrus and has a crisp finish
Shared 16.9 oz. bottle. Hazy gold with a white head. Aroma of citrus and tropical fruit. Taste is citrus, tropical fruit, malt and pine. Great balance. Really good.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2016 Bottle kindly shared by Cuso, thanks! Very very easy drinking and refreshing, well balanced. Well attenuated, clean clean hoppy flavours and aromas, fruity, resiny, citrusy, berries. Juiciness and character richness typical of the best examples. Real pleasure to drink.

Bottle kindly donated by coldbrewky, many thanks. Hazy yellow orange color with hug white head. Hoppy aroma with oranges, tangerines, pines, zest. Taste, citrus hops with oranges, zest, pines, caramel malt, spices. Long hoppy bitter finish. Tasty.

Bottle kindly shared by Cuso. Golden cloudy color, thick white head. Aroma is nice hoppy, fruity, zesty, resiny, piney, citrusy. Taste is pretty balanced, decent malty and hoppy, citrusy, zesty, piney, fruity. Very good

Awesome unique nose, with plenty of tropical fruit, some nuttiness, and doughy notes. Appearance is dark gold, slight haze, fine lace. Mouthfeel is juicy, ends dry. Thick and complex and not just another IPA. Thanks Wally. Anne likes it.
Draught. Deep golden pour with a thin fizzy head. Good lacing. Aroma of piney hops, vanilla, peach/mango and cereal. Medium body with a lasting bitter finish.

Grapefruit, pine, pineapple, passionfruit, mango, resin, light bready malts.
Golden colour, medium white head, lacing.
Big, big assertive bite, mid-sweet, ABV well integrated, zesty grapefruity, light floral perfume.
Medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long bitter finish.
A treat.
Whoop! got me a few bottles finally. Big hops yes, moderate body balances such hop oppression. Nose is light. Sturdy. Sparse lacing left behind from this quick drinker.

500 ml bottle, born on date of 050316. Served in a Spiegelau IPA glass, the beer pours a mostly clear gold color with a couple inch off-white head that stayed around for a really long time. Theres also a good amount of lacing. Aroma is really nice, the brew smells mostly like pine and citrusy (tropical fruit, grapefruit, peaches) hops, along with some bready malt. As soon as I poured this into the glass, the aroma was noticeable right away. I think the taste is pretty much just like the aroma, its mainly pine and citrusy (tropical fruit, citrus peel, grapefruit) hops with a bit of bready maltiness. With the aroma I thought the tropical fruit/citrusy hops stood out more, but it seemed to me that there was more balance between the pine and tropical fruit/citrusy flavors. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick with a good amount of carbonation. I liked this a lot, Id certainly like to try it again in the future. $6.99 a bottle.

On tap at the source as part of ECBT. Smallish pour to pace myself. Attractive clear, filtered IPA with predominantly golden notes. Aroma is reminiscent of almost an imperial IPA. Plenty of hops with pine and floral qualities. Taste is fresh and clean. Remarkably easy to drink with a pleasant bitterness offset by a malty sweet balance. Almost a grassy feel mid sip. Very professional effort. Expectations were high and this meets them with no issue. Coming away impressed.

Aroma: tons of floral flavors; no hops evident; Appearance: hazy golden/orange pour with white head that dissipates slowly; some lacing; Taste: all hops and no sweetness, but bitterness isnt overwhelming; Palate: medium body that initially finshes biitter and then with some sweetness; Overall: delicious IPA. Would buy again if available.

Draft at Giant Eagle in Grandview: gold pour with big fluffy white head. aroma of lemon, dank, resiny, fresh hops. tastes are crisp clean lemon, grapefruit, grass, light spice. light to moderate bitter throughout. look forward to getting a growler and spending more time with it.
Bottled. Poures brilliant gold amber lots of head, citrus and resin, dry finish. Really well balanced.

Orange yellow pour right away. Aroma juniper. Aroma is mild doughy onions. Light juniper palate light for an ipa, resinous elements are fantastic but the hops are faded.
7 months old

Cloudy bright orange pour with half inch white head. Bright citrus aroma with pungent zest, kind of orange juice-y, malt backbone floury, but of mint. Lively mouthfeel, fairly average mouthfeel, effervescent dry finish. Flavor has grass/straw, and has lots of citrus elements. Dry bitter zest, fresh orange juice, bitterness is palpable toward the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

July 22, 2015. On tap at the brewery. 
Clear dark golden with a small white head. Aroma is hoppy with a good amount of citrus, grassy, peach, pineapple, some pine notes and grain. Taste is medium sweet with ripe pineapple, peach, and mango, smooth medium bitterness leading to a dry grassy bitter finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation. 
Another great IPA from the east coast.

Draught at Rattle & Hum West, NYC. Hazy golden beer with a beautiful lasting offwhite head. Hoppy pine flavor, citrus, peach, caramel, grape fruit notes, mango, some biscuits. Hoppy citrus flavor, caramel, grapes, pine apples, peach and passion fruit. Smooth well balanced IPA. Maine know how to make great hoppy beers.

Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares feat. Aaron from Oregon 5.0. Pours hazy orange amber with a beige head. Aroma of pine, citrus, dank hops, orange, grapefruit and just nice and clean west coasty although its from the east. The taste has pine, oranges, citrus, grapefruit, lime and dank hops. Also some weak grain in there. Pretty nice!

Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares ft. Aaron from Oregon 5.0. Pours an almost clear orange with a small white head. Aromas of tropical fruits, piney, resiny, citrussy, fresh hops, light malty. Taste is resiny, malty, sticky, piney, orange peel, dank, grapefruit.
Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshare feat. Aaron from Oregon 5.0. Light hazy golden pour with a frothy head. Crisp, clean, resinous, pine, grapefruit and some light sweet malty caramel notes. Nice!

Smell like a beautiful bouquet of citrus fruits. Lovely foggy pale Orange color. Taste of grapefruit super heavy with some Orange juice little floral with a dry smooth finish. Big medium body with light crisp carbonation. Love this beer had it awhile ago remember liking it then had to get it again definitely great brew.

Tasted from draft. Pours a clear gold. Aroma is citrus fruit and some sweet caramel notes. Taste is very well balanced. Very minimal bitterness. Flavors of grapefruit, tropical fruit, caramel, crackers, toffee, floral notes. Very good IPA but not sure if quite lives up to the hype. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler filled today from a keg tapped today. Finely-hazed sunny gold pour with small head. Nose of tangerine juice, grapefruit sharpness, candied lemon rind, some flower petals, bread, creamy lychee and a modest helping of pine. Flavor is unripe and rindy, starts off smooth and clean with lemongrass and canned tangerine water, peaks to a high note of muddled floral bitterness, and finishes with a slight candied flavor of the aforementioned notes. The linger is lemongrass and filmy. The hype hasnt won me on this one. Its much more reserved than I expected, and the flavors dont have too great of a depth. There are local breweries here in my own city cranking out IPAs that smoke this one. However I dont intend to dismiss this brew as unworthy. Much like many of Maine Beer Cos works its super clean, very very crushable, and a well-crafted beer. But the hype? Its subjective. All palates are different.
One of my overall favorites after having only ONE of these, from a friend. Love sweetness of this bear that complements the complex hops. Many more in my future.

Pleasant citrus aroma with notes of pine. Appearance is a light gold with a thick white head. Flavor is crisp and full of citrus hops. Malt has notes of crackers. I slight vegetal taste is noticeable from the hops. Bitterness is medium high. Mouthfeel is medium with medium carbonation. Overall, it's a great tasting IPA. Great hop aroma and flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Man, what a beer. Its got a ton of hop aroma and its surprisingly clear for a "northeast" IPA, but the really amazing thing is its almost complete lack of bitterness. It just tastes like crisp, clean malt and aromatic hops. Genuinely world class.

Wow what a big disappointment! From the tap....maybe a bad batch? Fairly clear golden pour with lots of lacing left on the glass. Aroma was muted, but picked up slight fruity hops, and not much else. Taste was standard, to below standard for an IPA - watered down, minimal hop and malt taste. Blah!

Sample at Brass Tap Polaris. This beer pours a clear orange-gold color with a medium white head that dissipates steadily to a film. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of zesty citrus, grassy hops and malt. Medium body with flavors of tropical fruit, mango, herbal hops and toasted malt. The finish is moderately bitter with a lingering citrusy hops aftertaste. Solid IPA all around.

On tap at the Freeport brewery. Outstanding effort from Maine Beer and well worth the praise it has received. The genius of this beer is how it manages to balance the maltiness and ABV with the powerful aromatic hops. With so much hops on the nose and tongue, it shouldnt work as a strong ale but it finishes with a light sweetness and gentle bitterness. A desert island beer for certain.
From bottle dated at end of November. Standard ipa, well balanced but dont see the hype behind it.

The beers color is a light-ish golden amber. The liquid is fairly cloudy. Thick, white head. Lots of lacing. Very good head retention. The aroma is ruby red grapefruit, tangerine, kiwi, mango and pine. Fairly spicy, good amount of pine resin and grapefruit pith. Simple candy malt backbone. Light caramel. Taste has medium bitterness. Some light sugary sweetness but finishes quite dry. Good deal of pine and citrus hoppiness in the taste. Fair bit of astringency in the feel. Very light, otherwise. Some hop oiliness. Good beer.

Growler. Pours a slightly hazed gold with a nice, lasting head. Aroma is pine, earth, citric, and tropical hops, quite the medley. Flavor has just enough biscuity malt backbone to hold things together, but this was mostly just a very pleasant hop blast, matching the nose. Well done. Ive really liked what this brewery has been doing.
Pours gold with white hear and some lacing...alittle creamy. Aroma of bold tropical and light citrus fruit. Taste is the same with impressive bitterness.
Bottle shared by Brian. Pours a slightly hazy golden with a ring of off white head. Aroma and taste of citrus, floral hops, nice malty background.

Delicious, smooth, moderate hop and mild sweetness. Very easy drinking. World class. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

on tap @ Vino Bellissimo / Lima OH --- Clear light amber color, white head, curtain of lace. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste is clear malt, then light fizz and citrus hops on the swallow, drifting from there to a nice long hoppy finish. A solid IPA, pretty much hop dominated, but still well done.

Pour is a clear copper with a large and long-lasting fluffy tan head. Big yeast slug means that the final pour comes out hazy. The aroma is all sweet citrus. Flavor is more balanced, lots of citrus but also some yeast fruitiness, sweet malt. Fades to an aftertaste of pine and lemon. Soft and frothy mouthfeel with a clean finish. Good stuff, definitely agree with the West Coast deScriptor.

Fresh bomber served in a tulip. The beer is a cloudy straw yellow with a thick white head and nice lacing. Aroma is citrus, tropical, with a pine and caramel back. Taste is tropical, citrus, and caramel. Tons of fresh fruit flavors and some pine. Mouthfeel is creamy and juicy. One of the best ipas I have ever had.

On tap @ Whole Foods WL Chicago. Pour is hazy amber with a very small white head that fades quickly. Aroma and flavor are dominated by intense hops - pine, grapefruit, grass, and straw. Finish is similar with some slight booze coming through.

Lunch on tap at Gallos Tap Room enjoyed October 22, 2015. 

Look - Clear gold. Thin head from bar pour yet rings leaves nice lacing.

Smell - Pine. Orange. Grapefruit. Wheat. Grass.

Taste - Resinous pine. Bitter. Citrus is subdued in taste.

Feel - Carbonated from tap. Rips tongue. Not what Id call easy drinking but expected.

Overall - First Lunch to hit Ohio. Id like to try Mo, Peeper, or Another One but figured Id go with the mainstay. Classic IPA with a pine/bitter edge.

BOD 9/29/15. Almost clear yellow golden pour. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

Outstanding nose of zest (orange, lemon and slight grapefruit), a touch of spruce spiciness and a biscuit base.

Light medium body that has a slightly smooth texture. Slightly below normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a stronger finish.

The flavor profile is quite outstanding - reasonable intensity, complex and perfectly balanced. It is hop flavor, rather than bitterness, oriented. It begins with a blend of hop flavors indicated by the nose, with general zest being the most dominate. The middle is fairly bitter, but a bit light for an IPA. Bitterness is perfectly balanced with a subtle biscuit that never becomes sweet. The finish is a bit dry and hop flavor/bitterness lingers. As the finish fades, the spicy spruce aspects are at their strongest and tangerine notes are noted.
Lemon and pine dominated nose and flavor. A touch more bitter than the Trilliums or the Treehouse. 4th for me in that line-up, but thats by no fault - still an awesome brew. All 8.5s...

Sample at taproom. Pours golden with a thin white head. Leaves a lot of lacing in the glass. Not getting a lot on the nose. Big floral and grapefruit on the tongue. Finished clean. Solid but not feeling it as much as another one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours medium orange with a one finer white head with excellent lacing. Aroma is of citrus (mainly grapefruit), pine, tropical fruits, light grassy hops, and some light bready malts. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and a semi dry, moderately bitter, long finish. Overall, a fantastic west coast style IPA that tastes like something you would expect Alpine to brew.

7/12/2011 11:52:39 AM Bottle from Brattleboro Food Co-op. Fantastic. Nice hazy amber body with huge head. Nose of pines and fruits, grapefruit at that. Taste is also very heavenly hops and pines. Nice fruit tastes. Really, really good.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2016 On tap at the Foundry, served in a tulip. Very nice, well rounded IPA, priced out of the competitive range, however for what it is and how many similar offerings are available. Certainly this IPA smells amazing. Very citrusy, strong smell of oranges and slight bitterness of grapefruit. Smells just like sweet orange juice. Citrus abounds and equals the flavor of some left coast favorites and it has a decent  mildly bitter finish. Quite drinkable.
Bottle thanks to a trade. Bitter, but very tropical with a very nice malty backbone to balance it out. Great beer, loved every sip of it.

Tap at the brewery. It pours clear gold with a small white head. The nose is soft, juicy, clean, tropical fruit action, peach, tangerine and mango. The taste is crisp, clean, bitter, light minerals, bitter orange, peach, apricot, grapefruit, straw and some grass with a dry, peppery finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Crisp, clean, bitter and fruity. Very drinkable stuff. Tasty.

Cloudy goldenrod, ample white head. Big fresh notes of pine resin, grapefruit. Some lighter tropical fruits. Quite bitter, very muted malt character. Dry. Oily mouthfeel, strongish effervescence, medium body. Finish really lingers. Excellent.
5oz draft at the brewery. Darker gold than the Beautiful Little. Bright hoppiness to it with subtle pine notes and a bit of spice. High carbonation. Nice.

On tap: The aroma consists of moderate dank hops, citrus, and a hint of lemon. Ccc the flavor starts with citrus and a hint of tropical fruits. The finish has moderate grapefruit with a touch of lemon. Its light-medium bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Oh my. Aroma is sweet tropical fruit, some dankness, some malt, very fucking nice. Appearance is a nice light amber, opaque, white head, it?s beautiful. Taste is....balanced. I?m not getting a lot of any one thing. A little pine, a little dank, a little tropical fruit, bitter, but nothing stands out. Mouthfeel is a little light, but a good carbonation and the flavor hangs. Overall, this is truly disappointing from what I expected out of the aroma. Damn.

500 mL bottle courtesy of Al. Shared with ebone1988. The pour is an orangey gold color with a large frothy white head and some great lace. The aroma is great. There is such a lovely hoppiness. Such a good tropical fruit, hoppy juiciness, and a little bit of a malt sweetness on the back end. There is a subtle dankness on the back that I also love. The flavor is really piney and resin based up front. The bouquet of hops falls off drastically. The tropical fruits that existed become an afterthought. For a beer that started out with so much potential, it's disappointing. The mouth feel is slick and light with a decent carbonation, but then it just falls right off the tongue. The aftertaste has a lingering bite to it, but I can't tell if it's malt or hop. So disappointing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

OOPS! One of those I had a long time ago and never really rated. Poured a beautiful deep golden orange with a modest head. Aroma was citrus heavy with the tropical fruits and malted grains. The taste was very citrus fruit forward with some pine bitter hops on the back. The balance is amazing. Packed full of flavors. Medium carb and medium to light in body. One of my favs.
Really good! Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!Really good!
Lacks the aroma you expect but the perfect IPA. Slight sweetness, hop forward and great bitterness on the back end

Pours hazy light apricot with a frothy-foamy white head.. Aromas of grass, fir cones, apricot, peach, slight grapefeuit. Very balanced on the nose, nothing that screams out but very nice. Taste is likewise extremely well balanced: apricot, peach, passion fruit, citrus, fir cones. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Very good!!

Pours a clear, dark, golden color with a large bubbly head. Huge, fresh hop aroma. Sweet-smelling with tropical fruits and piney hops. Very bitter but approachable. This beer is lively and has a long finish. Truly a great IPA.
Pours golden with a nice white head. Aroma is a grassy citrus hop. Lots of hop flavor. Super clear. Light bodied.

Stumbled upon a single bottle of this in Jersey. Bottled July 21st. Less than 2 weeks old! Thin bright white head of fine bubbles. Succulent aroma with loads of ripe citrus (lemon and pineapple), some light grains and perfume. Color is a clear dark gold. Wow, a real hop bomb. Loads of bitterness that dries out the mouth. Grapefruit amd pine along with some dusty grains, lemon grass and only a light malt presence. Lacking any sweetness, this is one dry and puckering brew. Which is great if you like that kind of thing. Light alcohol presence. A little bit unbalanced for my liking but still a very solid hoppy IPA that gets the absolute most out of the hops it uses. Lucky to have found this!
Fantastic beer to receive in a trade as an extra. Need to pick up more. This ipa has fantastic taste and a strong piny smell.

Pours hazy orange with high white head
Aromas of grapefruit, citrus, pine
Taste has very nice hoppyness of grapefruit, citrus, hints of pine tesin caramel. Very well balanced

On tap, pours light golden with white frothy, clingy head. The citrus and fruit smells are amazing. Perhaps the smoothest, most balanced IPA Ive tried. This one begs for a long session. Everything good about the aroma comes through in the flavor. Finish is clean, and somewhat fruity. Best IPA Ive had to date. Great stuff.
Bottle at craigs. Pours hazy orange, nose is sweet toffee, pine, taste is dry, toffee, fruity.

Bottle thanks to Rob! Pours clear orange with a large white head. Aroma is peach, pine, spruce amnd tropical fruits. Taste is bitter initially, slight malt, grapefruit bitter, orange, mango and pineapple. Full body.

At cgarvieuks.
bottle at home .. light golden yellow ... small white head ... soft zezty floral orange nose ... zezty passion orange fruits .. soft sweet fruit ... soft floral fruits ...

I couldn't believe I was able to find this in the suburbs of Chicago. This was an excellent IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Torst. Milky golden pour with a white head. Resin aroma. Pine and citrus hop highlights. Well balanced. It has that mine rally characteristic that I find a bit off putting. Taste wise it fits right in with Portland, Oregon as opposed to Maine. Mellow orange zest finish. Average body and mouthfeel. Its solid but definitely not worth the hype.

Pours lightly hazy golden orange color with a 2 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate bready malt balance; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fair amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, peach, mango, lemon/peel, pine, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, fairly sticky, and slightly creamy mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming after the finish. Overall this is an awesome IPA. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate bready malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

I find a bright grapefruit; fresh, ripe apricots; a brilliant spruce accent as soon as the cap is lifted and the sweetness of the fruits are lifted up over the neck like a soft cloud of smells. I immediately want a fresh strawberry to add into the glass, but know that I would only cut my experience in half if I did it.
The liquid is cool on my tongue, the carbonation at perfect levels to deliver this brew. The head is soft and eggshell in color, dense and lacing the glass heavily, never actually disappearing, but diminishing slowly as I drink. The bitterness of this IPA is evenly distributed throughout my mouth, the carbonation helping it to find its way over and underneath my tongue, biting it steadily with its beautiful hops edge and then disappearing down my throat with a whisper of caramel and pine left behind. Its finish is gentle for an IPA, but Im sure that anything I drink immediately afterward will surely be twisted by the strength of this combination of taste and flavor.
The remainder of this beer will be tasted as carefully as the initial glass; review or no review, this is a treat for me and one I plan to savor!

IPA complexe au parfums de fruits tropicaux, cette bière est une fière représentante de son style. Dune riche robe blonde/orangée, cette bière est surmontée dun épais collet blanc et onctueux qui fait saliver. Mise en garde: servir délicatement! Au nez cette bière est un aller simple pour les tropiques. Ça transpire le punch aux fruits: kiwis, ananas, fraises, noyau de pêche. Mon Dieu que cest frais et plein de vie! Une avalanche de fines bulles émanent sans relâche du fond du verre et invite à une dégustation des plus rafraîchissantes! En bouche on poursuit dans la même veine et leffervescence piquotle agréablement le palais et confère à cette bière une texture plus sèche et minérale quattendue. Un côté marin sajoute aux fruits. Nous sommes vraiment au sein dun splendide voyage sous les tropiques dont on ne veut revenir! Cest frais, nerveux, complexe et long en bouche. La présence du malt est parfaitement balancée aux houblons. Un énorme coup de coeur pour moi!

Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a dark brown, nearly black color with a one finger head of a thick creamy head of an off white color. The head fades rather quickly leaving a little bit of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 
 Smell  The aroma of the beer is big of tropical fruit smell of tangerine, pineapple, and papaya mixed with a nice aroma of a ruby red grapefruit. Along with the grapefruit are aromas of a pine and slightly grassy smell.

 Taste  The taste begins a much drier than anticipated flavor with some slightly bready and crackery flavors mixed with a moderately strong grapefruit hop. As the taste advances, the grapefruit remains at a relatively constant level with the light level of sweetness that was present upfront (lighter tangerine and tropical fruit flavor) fading and being replaced by more hop flavors. The hop flavors that replace the sweet are a mix of a grassy and pine flavor, with the combination of flavors leaving a nice crisp somewhat drier blend of hop flavors to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is lighter side for a beer of 7 % abv with a carbonation level that was rather average. For the crisp feel of the brew, in conjunction with the drier flavors the slightly thinner body and moderate carbonation were quite nice as they made it quite refreshing and crisp all while not compromising the nice fruit and hop flavors of the brew.

 Overall  A nice and tasty IPA that is a bit on the drier side but has a great flavor and drinkability. Quite nice.

Ok, so Im highly suggestible, but what else was I supposed to do with a beer called "Lunch", other than have it with lunch? And it worked - it was a very pleasant IPA with lunch. This is a particularly good IPA: the hop profile is quite enthusiastic, to the point that its almost on par with a DIPA. Not a hop bomb or a palate wrecker by any means, but definitely hoppy and interesting, with just enough malt to balance the hop bitterness. This is IPA the way it should be: hop forward, with malt providing support in the background. Their description if it as being an "east coast version of a west coast-style IPA" is bang on. Think big west coast IPA, but without the dankness.

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 8/13/13 and cost $7 ($0.41 per ounce) (thanks to Jon H. for selling it to me).

Appearance: Burnt umber/rusty orange hue. So hazy that its opaque. Forms a large, white, frothy head which laces and retains wonderfully.

Smell: Stone fruit with significant vegetable component of garlic and other seasonings.

Taste: 2013 has been the year of the New England IPA for me. Ive had quite a few beers of the style from breweries Ive never been able to try before, and I notice theres an eerie similarity to their taste. However, what they also have in common is my enjoyment of them. And while Maine Beer Company Lunch is another great example of the regional style, I think Ive reached a point where it doesnt impress me as much as it once did.

Like the other New England IPAs, "Lunch," is a palette of two distinctive movements. Up front its sweet and juicy with a tropical fruit flavor of passion fruit, guava and red grapefruit. Then it transforms on a dime to garlic and green onion with a residual flavor of spice rack seasonings (which become stronger as the beer warms). The bitterness is noticeable throughout, but restrained, and complements the palette nicely. Theres an arid dryness as it finishes, though it fades away quickly. The body is well-balanced with plenty of amber and pale maltiness, but I wouldnt consider it a sweet or malty beer per se. Overall, its a very good IPA, and Id probably rate it higher if I hadnt already had so many comparable beers prior. 

Drinkability: Though plenty robust and full-bodied, "Lunch" is a remarkably easy drinker. The mouthfeel is calm and soft, with an almost creamy texture and smooth finish. There is a slight aftertaste of spicy hops and general dryness, but its mild and tolerable. Each swig is refreshing for a short moment as it crosses the tongue. At 7% ABV its a strong beer, but not an obtuse one. Its also versatile as it can be enjoyed on its own or with a meal.

I was at a Maine Beer night at the Blind Tiger Ale House about a month ago. I knew I would love this beer from the description so I left it for last. Big mistake...just when I got thru all the other Maine beers and asked for Lunch...the keg had kicked! I begged the bartender to splash some foam into a tasting glass and fortunately he did. From that I was able to tell a lot...especially the aroma (nice hoppy and citrusy smell) and a good sense of the palate & mouthfeel. Obviously I couldnt judge the appreance (other than "empty"...LOL!). Low & behold a day later I wandered into Murrays Cheese Bar (the new bar/restaurant...not the store) and with only 6 taps there was Lunch just sitting there waiting to be pulled. Needless to say I availed myself of a couple. I then came back twice over the next 3 days until I pretty much killed it. Apparently no other beer geeks had discoved this place or its hidden jewel in the interim...LOL! Lucky me. So I can report that the appreance was very nice...a somewhat pale golden amber. I can also say that having drank as much of it as I did I became a big fan. I also had a chance to notice more of the flavors and character of this complex and very pleasing beer...to enjoy the hop smell and flavor. The beer is piney...but not as much as say a Heady Topper. Also flavors of fruits...something between an apricot and peach. My hat is off the Maine Beer company for this stellar effort. I hope they make more soon...it went too fast!

500ml bottle into a New Belgium goblet.

A: Pours a hazy orange-copper color. Very hazy, actually. About two fingers of fluffy, off-white head is formed, and the retention is fabulous. The lacing left on the glass is both sudsy and plentiful.

S: Unsurprisingly, its loaded with citrusy hops. I notice grapefruit, mango, apricot, and melon alongside some more typical pine notes. Slight biscuity maltiness is evident, too. While it didnt quite blow me away like I expected it to, its still a great aroma, head-and-shoulders above many IPAs.

T: The citrus notes are even more evident on the flavor profile. A huge opening of fresh grapefruit, apricot, melon, and mango provides an evocative juiciness that I love. Mild pine bitterness and slight biscuity tones appear on an otherwise clean finish. This really does a fantastic job of showcasing fruity hops in a balanced manner.

M: Pretty much ideal here: clean, crisp, bone-dry, low bitterness, and light. Id call it easy to drink, but this is one of those beers I dont want to end. Soft carbonation adds to the wonderful mouthfeel.

O: Its easy to see why this is hyped. As far as east-coast IPAs go, I cant think of one thats on this level - maybe super-fresh Troegs Perpetual IPA or Flower Power? Obviously I havent sampled any of the (supposed) Vermont masterpieces, but Id still imagine this one is really high up the totem pole regardless. And to think I was ready to complain about MBC pricing before sampling this - Id gladly pay $8/500ml for this one again. And again, and again, and again...
